data.shownotes: All songs are the earliest confirmed performances as there are no known earlier public performance dates. This short set was for "assessment moderation purposes" for the RMIT University Bachelor of Contemporary Music Performance Exams. The end of the performance featured the first known public usage of the name King Gizzard and the Lizard Wizard, which had been decided on at an earlier unknown date. KGLW.net Staff Notes: The date of this show has been confirmed with the professor that recorded and uploaded the video. We note that these are the "first confirmed performances" as there is no record of any earlier ones; however it can be assumed that some or all of these songs had been publicly performed earlier at unknown dates and locations. Ambrose and Cook are missing from the performance most likely because they were not studying the Bachelor of Contemporary Music Performance. Their status as band members is undefined, though they were both playing regularly with the band around this time, as well as several other people who did not become permanent members. Through 2010 King Gizzard were a house party band with an open roster who wrote their songs pretty much on the fly. The fact that they had a name and five original songs here tells us the band was becoming moderately established and would soon start releasing singles and booking billed gigs.

KGLW.net Staff Notes: The setlist for this show is believed to be complete, but no recordings are available. KGLW.net staff believes the setlist is complete based on the written setlist for the show, but any additional setlist notations that require audio confirmation (segues, quotes or teases) may be incomplete. The date is believed to be correct, but is based on the upload date for Sleep / Summer on Soundcloud and may be incorrect. If anyone has any further information or, ideally, a complete or conclusive recording please contact KGLW.net staff at setlists@kglw.net.

This show was believed to be held as a celebration for the 500th issue of Forte Magazine. The recording was seemingly distributed on cassette tape, of which only two copies are known to exist. The previously unknown song is believed to be Gypsy. Ghost is a cover of a song by Goodnight Owl (a.k.a. Love Migrate), a defunct band that included Joey and Eric. Lunch Meat was performed with the alternate arrangement heard on the demo released on Demos Vol. 5. During the intro of Fried, which contained a Surf Rider (The Lively Ones) tease, Joey announced that Stu had gotten too fried and had left the band, which Stu apologized for and repeated that he's "just a normal person." During the song Stu broke three of his guitar strings. After Fried, Stu asked if anyone had a guitar with more than one string, then congratulated Forte on their 500th issue, followed by Joey advertising their new CDs (likely early Anglesea copies).
